1089485343794126848.text: And watch out for anyone trying to pivot the conversation about #HolocaustMemorialDay to anything else. That's the problem.

1089485339197087749.text: There are a lot of things to talk about regarding World War 2. A lot of people suffered, and not just at Nazi hands. But today, on #HolocaustMemorialDay , with anti-Semitism on the rise, it's very important that we #NeverForget exactly what happened, and how it happened.

1089485327499186176.text: About 9 million Jews lived in mainland Europe in 1933. 6 million were killed in the Holocaust. Across the continent, nearly two in three were systematically murdered. Of the three million Jews in Poland in 1933, only 45,000 survived.

1089485323455942656.text: The French and Dutch like to talk about the resistance. Italians like to talk about the German occupation. These are easy to understand, and they are uncomplicated. The Holocaust is complicated. There is nothing redemptive, only pain. It gets shunned to the side of main events.

1089485320830287872.text: The focus can shift to Nazi imperialism, to politics, to national myths of resistance, to bravely standing alone. The Soviet version manages to combine all of them, and completely removes Jews from the story. So do many others. Brits like to talk about surviving the Blitz.

1089485317890101248.text: Last week I tweeted about Tony Judt's Postwar: A History of Europe Since 1945. One of the central themes of the book is Europe's inability to accept that World War 2 was about the Jews. Countries try to turn it into something else, and repress the unpleasant memories.

Fact of the day: before the shift to the Gregorian calendar in 1752, New Year's Day was 25th March. This is why months (Sept, Oct, Nov, Dec) are numbered from March.

July 1740 happened before February 1740.

January and February 1752 never happened (in the UK).

1072995728442707968.text: Today highlighted how May's deal cannot get through Parliament. The ERC, DUP, and Remainer Conservatives hate if for three different reasons. Brussels will not change the deal offered, so the vote cannot be won in Jan. 6/7

1072995725808754688.text: Conservative MPs backed May's approach, but not her. The winners were the senior Tories who publicly backed her, and can set themselves up as successors. Think Sajid Javid.  Meanwhile, we have Brexit to deal with. 5/7

1072995724089016320.text: So, did the opposition win? Well, no. Labour are talking about a vote of no confidence in the house, but they don't think they can win it. The EHC wouldn't vote against May incase Corbyn won, and the DUP would lose influence in a new parliament. 4/7

1072995721803120640.text: However, May lost too. She has stated she will not be leader by 2022 to win the vote, and she wanted to keep the job. She's lost the Premiership, and a lot of influence. She won't leave office tomorrow, but today she lost the job. 3/7

1072995719454384129.text: To be clear, the ERC (pro-Brexit group of Conservative MPs) lost. They really thought they could put one of their own, Johnson or JRM as PM, and that the party would follow. It did not. They wasted the chance, and cannot challenge for another year. 2/7

1056992789232259077.text: Particularly in the current political climate, understanding how the public can fall under the sway of a far-right demagogue is more important than ever. The Nazis, and Hitler, need to be more than a punchline. I'd fully encourage everyone to read it. And I mean everyone.

1056991602651074560.text: You hear how awful the Nazis were so often it almost loses meaning, but it shouldn't. It mustn't. I almost threw up reading first hand accounts of the Holocaust. National Socialism is an abomination, and everyone should understand why. What it was, what it did, and how it did it.

1056990011390918656.text:
Finally finished the longest book I've ever read, The Rise and Fall of the Third Reich by William L. Shirer.

I certainly disagree with a lot of what Shirer thinks (the homophobia etc.), but it is really something. How Nazi Germany came into being, written by someone present.

1005899320011513857.text: When you see on Facebook that over 400,000 people fell for a fake news story about Back to the Future 4

1005769891947909120.text: Never underestimate the power of a random act of kindness. Just little things. When someone feels hopeless, they can mean everything.

1005446774172119040.text: If you are suffering, remember: today, you are you, and that's enough. When you're stuck in that hole that you can't get out of, we've been there. We know the way out. If you are alone, somebody's coming. We'll take you home. Don't be scared. You are not alone. 16/

1005446772485959680.text: If you know someone who's going through this, I hope this gives you some insight into what might be going on in their mind. You don't need to fix it for them, and they don't expect you to. Just being there means the world. 15/

1005446771366121472.text: Sometimes faith in the idea that at some point everything won't be so painful and confusing is the only thing that keeps me going. It's not much, but it's enough. 14/

1005446768979578880.text: As it stands, I'm actively depressed, and have been for about two months. At times, it feels like this is all I'll ever know. But, deep down, I know that at some point in the future I'll probably feel better. I can't see it now, but I will. 13/

1005446767633207296.text: And when you do feel depressed again, you might not be at your best, but you're not broken. Don't ever believe you are broken. I did. It removed any sense of self-worth. Not thinking that your own thoughts & opinions are valid because your brain doesn't work properly is tough 12/

1005446765519269890.text: Here's the point I want to get to. Depression isn't something that gets fixed. Thinking of it like that isn't helpful. It's destructive. It's something you live with. There are good times, & there are bad times. That's all part of it. It isn't failure to feel depressed again. 11/

1005446763665379328.text: This is when you shut people out completely. Because there is something hugely wrong with you if you haven't fixed yourself yet. You fear that if you fail again, they'll give up on you. They'll walk away. You're too much effort. It would break your heart. 10/

1005446761551450112.text: Eventually, it passes. You begin to put yourself back together, and then convince yourself that this time you're finally going to be fine. But it isn't, because a few weeks or months later there is another relapse. And it feels much worse this time. 9/

1005446759529803776.text: You feel like you've let everyone down, and you start acting strangely. You just want to be normal. You want to pain to stop. There are seven billion people on earth, but you're stuck being you. In my experience, this is where suicidal thoughts enter the picture. 8/

1005446758074388480.text: Each relapse follows a similar pattern. First I start getting agitated by minor things. Then I stop eating and sleeping. Then I fall apart. Then I try covering it up. When you relapse, you feel like a failure. You don't want people to know that you didn't fix it. 7/

1005446756736421888.text: My first relapse was six months after I was diagnosed, and it was the scariest part of the process. I thought I was fixed, then suddenly I wasn't. The pain, the negative voice, I wasn't supposed to have fixed this. Why hadn't I fixed it. What was wrong with me. 6/

1005446754278563840.text: I live in two states. I call these 'actively depressed' and 'remission'. I alternate between the two states every couple of weeks. As a rule, the longer I spend in remission, the bigger the pain when I relapse. Relapse isn't a good word, but it's the best I can think of. 5/

1005446753036984321.text: The thing is, depression doesn't work like that. Opening up and asking for help that first time is a huge step, but it's one step. The journey afterwards is very confusing. When I was first diagnosed, I wish someone could have explained this bit to me. 4/

1005446751166361601.text: When I was first diagnosed, I thought I could take anti-depressants for a few months and then it would be fixed. I would be cured. I had the big 'open-up-to-everyone' moment, I had the support, & then I sat down to a few months of self-help. This is the bit people talk about. 3/

1005446749287219200.text: Firstly, my name is Jamie. I'm 24, and I've suffered with depression my whole life, though I only got it diagnosed about two years ago. I've had many ups and downs over the last two years, including being suicidal for a brief period last October/November. 2/

1005446746724552709.text: Over the last few days my Twitter has been dominated by people sharing their depression and suicidal stories. It's so important to know that you're not going through these things alone. Here's a thread of my story, and what living with depression is like. I hope it helps you. 1/
